In vanilla with 6 charisma you don't get anything useful from the fifth cot level (divine wrath is unusable with low cha), so maybe four is enough. I would go something like 8 fighter / 4 cot / 18 dd. At least 7 fighter is needed for either cot and dd (7 bab prereq), and you get some goodies from that 18 dd - an extra feat and +3 dr. Another spread could be 8 fighter / 8 cot / 14 dd, for one more feat and better saves, but a small loss in dr.
Warhammer-shield is possible for dwarven in vanilla, I don't know if arelith changed this.
For starting abilities, something like this looks better to me:
STR 16
DEX 12
CON 18
WIS 8
INT 14
CHA 6

EDIT: I realized that dodge is a prereq for dd, so 13 dex is a must... you could drop one point from int (16/13/18/8/13/6), or two from con and get one more str too (17/13/16/8/14/6).

Valehand wrote:
This is mildly confusing. Are...you guys saying COT should be replaced with Rogue? Or ...I've gotten a little lost.
Ok, let me try to clarify and comment a bit.

1st, you don't really need Rogue for the purpose of this build, but it'd admittedly be very nice to have. What would Rogue bring to the build?
1- Use Magic Device (UMD). That would allow your character to buff himself up with scrolls and wands and equip class-specific gear, such as Monk boots. MAJOR BOOST
2- Tumble as a Class Skill. (The AC isn't that vital, though, as this guy tanks with DR, not AC). meh
3- A few extra skill points and a MUCH BETTER SKILLSET to pick from. Unfortunately, this build doesn't have nearly enough skill points to take advantage of the Rogue skillset.
4- EVASION! Deserving capital letters! All traps would have a chance of not doing damage to you.
5- A mild Sneak Attack damage bonus. meh again

What does Rogue cost this build? 2 Feats (Cot 2 and 4) (which this guy can afford). Drop Expertise and Called Shot. You have Defensive Stance, which is better than Expertise, and you're a CON monster, so you don't have such a high AB that you can afford losing 5 points to have higher AC. You tank with DR, not AC!

As for Rua's and hunaero's exchange, let me say this. Rua, if keeping the build as is, with the crappy skillset that he has to choose from, I would not drop ANYTHING for INT or DEX, because DwDs are immune to Sneak Attacks, so no need to spot sneakers. However, IF you bring in Rogue, your suggestion is SPOT ON!

Hunaero, he's absolutely right about Called Shot, drop that thing! You can't afford the AB having spent so many points in CON to consistently nerf your opponents. It's better to have just KD and be better at it than to have both and barely land a hit. Maybe your AB is high enough to hit with CS on the first attack each round, but from that point on you'll most likely miss, making the feat questionable to say the least.

Also KD is WAY more important than Improved Critical, simply because to crit you need to hit your threat roll to apply the bonus damage, and again, that AB is only average. You're a tank, not a heavy hitter. I would even drop IC if I had something better to swap it for. So Take KD ASAP (Level 3) and delay IC (if you take it at all) to level 18.

Does this all make sense?

Hey Valehand!
I like most of it, but it still needs improvement. I would start with fewer points in CON and more in STR (also, try to end in an even number on STR,even if you drop DEX to 13, cuz 14 means nothing since you will be wearing full plate anyway and negating that bonus). There's really no point in going over 22 CON (21 is requirement for EDR feats, which you should absolutely take, as you did, 22 is the next round number). It's even preferable to end on 21 CON and 22 STR, because STR gives AB, which this build needs as much as it can get.

As for the feats, prioritize EDR feats, not AB. You're a tank, so tank first, hit later! You will take the exact same feats, in a different order, following the following priority schedule:
1- EDR feats
2- Armor Skin
3- EWF / EWS
4- EP (Epic Prowess)

I don't like Lightning Reflexes. Great Fortitude is better, to resist high-DC death spells.

The rest is OK, I guess, but you didn't post the skill schedule, so I can't help you there. Download the CBC, man! It can be found under the Builder Tools section!

Good improvement! Get to work on the tweaks! Cheers!

Okay, I've hunkered down in my bolt-hole, so I reckon I can take what's coming...

I think there's a lot to be said for building on paper, with a redoubtable pen (actually, pencil is probably better) nearby. Yes, it's tougher to work through the calculations, but it does give you a real feel for the build. You challenge every feat you take - the why and the when - as well as the sequencing of classes (admittedly, somewhat different with Arelith), so you know what you're trying to accomplish with it through and through. You also start to recognise what skills you need, and when you need them. I know I've been guilty of mucking up skills schedules before - and more than likely will be again - but environment is probably even more important when it comes to allocating skills than it is for feats (things like whether Dev Crit is disabled being excepted, obviously). How you stand up to taunts and magic. Whether you can prevent your party being blown into tiny pieces. Whether you can blow your foes into said pieces. Just as a quick guide - from one who also doesn't use CBC - you'll get 2 skill points to distribute for every level of DwD and Fighter and 8 for every level of Rogue (all plus the INT modifier, and character level 1 taking four times the usual amount). If you played as human (impossible in this case), you'd get an extra 1 point per level regardless of class.

Thus, with an INT of 14 (+2),4  levels of Rogue gets you 40 skill points, and 26 levels of DwD/Fighter garners you 100 (25 multiplied by 4) plus 16 from Fighter at level 1. So 156.

If you took Rogue as the first level (or 3, in Arileth), you'd have 30 points from 3 "ordinary" Rogue levels plus 40 from level 1, and 104 (26 multiplied by 4) from the other two classes. So 174.

Them's the basics. If there are other modifiers you need to factor in, please do!
